data.text:
A bachelorâs degree in communications is an excellent starting point for a career in journalism, broadcasting, public relations, and a host of other exciting fields. As a communications major, youâll study language, group dynamics, non-verbal interaction, and more. Majoring in communication can qualify you for a wide range of professional opportunities in business, education, mass media, and more.

A degree in communication may also prepare you for work as a technician in broadcast, film editing, and a host of other media-related technical roles. Exceptional communication skills could also qualify you for a leadership role in a variety of organizational settings. The best schools for communications are those which are regionally accredited, which offer a full array of communications concentrations, and which give you the chance to work with the best and most influential professors and classmates.

Degree popularity: Communication bachelorâs degrees are the 21th most popular undergraduate degrees across all student demographics. Itâs slightly more popular among women, according to the number of degree earners reported by the National Center for Educational Statistics.

Why Communication Degrees Result in Excellent Careers

The digital era has drastically changed how people see the world and how they receive and access information. But why is a communications degree a good career choice? And what are the unique career opportunities that await you after completing this program?

You will become qualified for job opportunities that you never knew existed

Developing your communication skills can can prepare you for a traditional career in news, media, design, television, and more. But did you know there are also surprisingly interesting career paths you can achieve from communication programs?

A communications graduate could become a curator-in-chief, a story producer, or a music supervisor! Many unique job opportunities are available in the diverse world of communication.

You will make money

Communication and journalism are among the college majors with the highest earnings. Many degree holders in this field even pursue careers in politics or law.

Your ideas are valued

The field of communication is a very broad one. Many communications majors are creative. Creative people have some of the highest job satisfaction rates. They find their jobs interesting, make a lot of decisions, and find many opportunities to take the initiative.

You can work from anywhere

Entrepreneurship and freelancing are two scary words, but the rewards of working on your own and following your schedule outweigh the risks!

A degree in communication is great if you love traveling. Whether chasing a scoop or working on an assignment, freelance jobs in communication give you a chance to work remotely. All you really need is an Internet connection.

Designers, documentarians, wander lusters, and reporters alike all know how amazing it is to live this kind of lifestyle.

Common Areas of Study in Communications Degree Programs

Advertising and Marketing

This is the act of using communication as the primary means of promoting something like a brand, a product, an organization, or a business.

In a degree program in advertising and marketing communications, students are taught how to use an applicable communication theory and leverage the media to communicate with an audience effectively.

Usual topics of study in this program include:

audience identification

social media

digital marketing

marketing methods

business finance

public relations

Broadcasting

This program teaches students how to write, direct, and produce media content for distribution. Broadcasting refers to media that goes out to televisions, radio, and other streaming media services.

Communication Education

In this masterâs degree program, students study how communication and information influence our education and culture. The drive is to understand better how education and communication intersect so students in this program can ultimately teach and handle courses related to communication.

Electronic and Digital Media Communication

This degree prepares college students to interrelate with the more modern forms of communication, including television, social media, and other internet-based devices.

Students will learn how to deliver stories using modern communication methods, like producing reports for television or producing videos for various websites. Usual career paths for electronic and digital media communication degree holders include video production, newscasting, photography, sports reporting, and radio programming.
